thread.title: Attenborough, 90, to present BBC 'Blue Planet' sequel
thread.title_full: Attenborough, 90, to present BBC 'Blue Planet' sequel

title: Attenborough, 90, to present BBC 'Blue Planet' sequel
text:
UK   11:24am GMT Attenborough, 90, to present BBC 'Blue Planet' sequel File Photo: David Attenborough poses next to a portrait of himself by Bryan Organ to mark his 90th birthday at New Walk Museum and Art Gallery in Leicester, Britain, September 22, 2016. REUTERS/Darren Staples/File Photo 
LONDON Britain's most revered TV naturalist David Attenborough, 90, is returning to present a sequel to "The Blue Planet" documentary series, 16 years after the original illuminated the depths of the world's oceans. 
"Blue Planet II" will air later this year on the BBC, and follows the 2001 series which vividly depicted marine life from across the world and won two Emmys and two Baftas for its music and cinematography. 
The BBC said the new series will feature phenomena such as methane volcanoes in the Gulf of Mexico and the Pacific Ocean's so-called 'boiling sea', as well as footage from 1,000 metres under the Antarctic Ocean. 
"I am truly thrilled to be joining this new exploration of the underwater worlds which cover most of our planet, yet are still its least known," Attenborough said. 
The series follows his critically acclaimed series "Planet Earth II", which was broadcast in Britain last year. It was the most watched natural history programme for at least 15 years, the BBC said, and premiered in the U.S. on Saturday. 
Attenborough is also known for his work on the "Life" series of nine documentaries made over a 30-year period from 1979. 
(Reporting by Alistair Smout; editing by Stephen Addison) Next In UK
